input: DOCTOR: What brings you in today?\nPATIENT: I'm a 12-year-old boy. Lately, my hands and feet feel really numb and tingly, and I keep getting hurt even though I don’t notice right away. I fall a lot and feel kind of weak in my legs, and I guess I just wanted to see what’s going on with me.
output:
THINKING: The recent conversation introduced new clinical details: the patient is a 12-year-old boy experiencing numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, frequent unnoticed injuries, recurrent falls, and weakness in the legs. These are all confirmed facts and are added to the existing vignette. Since there are no prior details from earlier conversations, the vignette now contains only the latest confirmed facts provided by the patient.

ANSWER: The patient is a 12-year-old boy presenting with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, frequent injuries that he does not notice immediately, recurrent falls, and weakness in his legs.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: I'm a 12-year-old boy. Lately, my hands and feet feel really numb and tingly, and I keep getting hurt even though I don’t notice right away. I fall a lot and feel kind of weak in my legs, and I guess I just wanted to see what’s going on with me.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
PATIENT: Um, I think it started a little while ago, maybe a few months? At first it was just a tingling feeling in my feet, but then it kind of moved up my legs and sometimes my hands too. It gets worse when I walk or move around a lot, I guess, and I don't really know what makes it better. Sometimes resting helps a little, but not always. I just feel kind of off most of the time.
output:
THINKING: The latest conversation confirms and adds details to the patient's symptoms, including the temporal onset ("a few months ago"), the progression starting in the feet and moving up the legs and sometimes affecting the hands, symptoms worsening with activity, partial relief with rest, and a general feeling of being "off." These facts are consistent with, and expand upon, the earlier confirmed clinical presentation.

ANSWER: The patient is a 12-year-old boy presenting with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, which began a few months ago. The symptoms started in his feet and progressively involved his legs and sometimes his hands. He experiences frequent injuries that he does not notice immediately, falls often, and reports weakness in his legs. The symptoms worsen with walking or movement, and resting provides partial relief. He feels generally "off" most of the time.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: I'm a 12-year-old boy. Lately, my hands and feet feel really numb and tingly, and I keep getting hurt even though I don’t notice right away. I fall a lot and feel kind of weak in my legs, and I guess I just wanted to see what’s going on with me.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
PATIENT: Um, I think it started a little while ago, maybe a few months? At first it was just a tingling feeling in my feet, but then it kind of moved up my legs and sometimes my hands too. It gets worse when I walk or move around a lot, I guess, and I don't really know what makes it better. Sometimes resting helps a little, but not always. I just feel kind of off most of the time.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me how these symptoms have been affecting your daily activities, and whether you've noticed anything else that's changed or bothering you during this time?
PATIENT: Um, well, I guess everything feels a little more different now, like I get tired easier and sometimes I can't feel stuff in my feet or hands. It's kinda scary because I bump into things a lot or don't notice when I hurt myself. And I think I’ve been more dizzy than before, especially when I stand up too quickly.
output:
THINKING: The conversation has confirmed and expanded on the patient's symptoms, providing details on onset, progression, activity-related worsening, partial relief with rest, and associated sensations like numbness, tingling, fatigue, dizziness, and occasional unnoticed injuries. No new confirmed clinical findings are introduced in this segment.
ANSWER: The patient is a 12-year-old boy presenting with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet that began approximately a few months ago. The numbness started in the feet and gradually involved the legs and sometimes the hands. He experiences frequent injuries that he does not notice immediately, falls often, and reports weakness in his legs. Symptoms tend to worsen with walking or movement and improve somewhat with rest. He describes feeling generally "off" most of the time, with increased tiredness and dizziness, especially upon standing quickly.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: I'm a 12-year-old boy. Lately, my hands and feet feel really numb and tingly, and I keep getting hurt even though I don’t notice right away. I fall a lot and feel kind of weak in my legs, and I guess I just wanted to see what’s going on with me.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
PATIENT: Um, I think it started a little while ago, maybe a few months? At first it was just a tingling feeling in my feet, but then it kind of moved up my legs and sometimes my hands too. It gets worse when I walk or move around a lot, I guess, and I don't really know what makes it better. Sometimes resting helps a little, but not always. I just feel kind of off most of the time.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me how these symptoms have been affecting your daily activities, and whether you've noticed anything else that's changed or bothering you during this time?
PATIENT: Um, well, I guess everything feels a little more different now, like I get tired easier and sometimes I can't feel stuff in my feet or hands. It's kinda scary because I bump into things a lot or don't notice when I hurt myself. And I think I’ve been more dizzy than before, especially when I stand up too quickly.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how you've been feeling overall, including any changes you've noticed in your energy, balance, or daily activities, and whether you've experienced any other symptoms along the way?
PATIENT: Umm, I don’t know, I guess I just feel really tired sometimes, but I’m not sure if that’s normal. My balance is worse, and I fall more than I used to. My injuries don’t seem to hurt much, but they take a long time to heal, which is kind of scary. I’ve been feeling a bit dizzy when I stand up, and I don’t really understand what’s going on with all of this.
output:
THINKING: The latest conversation reiterates previous symptoms and adds emphasis to the progression, such as the worsening balance, slower healing of injuries, and increased frequency of falls and injuries. The details about activity-related symptom worsening, partial relief with rest, numbness, tingling, fatigue, dizziness, and problems with sensation and injuries are confirmed. No new clinical findings are introduced.  
ANSWER: The patient is a 12-year-old boy presenting with numbness and tingling in his hands and feet that started approximately a few months ago. The numbness began in the feet and gradually involved the legs and sometimes the hands. He experiences frequent injuries that he does not notice immediately, falls often, and reports weakness in his legs. Symptoms tend to worsen with walking or movement and improve somewhat with rest. He describes feeling generally "off" most of the time, with increased tiredness and dizziness, especially upon standing quickly. His balance is worse, and injuries take a long time to heal.
